commits.message:
Reinstate client_cert_verifier/server_cert_verifier

Both were accidentally disabled in b14505488 when they were made
conditional on a non-existent `webpki` feature.

pull_request.title: Separate server hints list from accepted trust anchors
pull_request.body:
This branch resolves https://github.com/rustls/rustls/issues/1549 by updating the default webpki client certificate verifier to allow configuring a server's client root certificate subject hints list separately from the subjects present in the root cert store used to verify client certificates. This is a useful capability in the presence of cross-signing when there are circumstances (described in #1549 and the updated rustdoc comments in this branch) where a server may want to hint to a client that it accepts a certificate with a given subject, without adding it to the server's trust store. 

See individual commit messages for more detail.

repo.name: rustls

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +44,35 @@ impl ClientCertVerifierBuilder {
         }
     }
 
+    /// Replace the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the client as hints of acceptable trust
+    /// anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn with_hint_subjects(
+        mut self,
+        subjects: impl IntoIterator<Item = DistinguishedName>,
+    ) -> Self {
+        self.hint_subjects = subjects.into_iter().collect();
+        self
+    }
+
+    /// Add an additional [`DistinguishedName`] to the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the
+    /// client as hints of acceptable trust anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn add_hint_subject(mut self, subject: DistinguishedName) -> Self {
comment.body: Yeah, that's probably the more explicit option.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +44,35 @@ impl ClientCertVerifierBuilder {
         }
     }
 
+    /// Replace the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the client as hints of acceptable trust
+    /// anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn with_hint_subjects(
+        mut self,
+        subjects: impl IntoIterator<Item = DistinguishedName>,
+    ) -> Self {
+        self.hint_subjects = subjects.into_iter().collect();
+        self
+    }
+
+    /// Add an additional [`DistinguishedName`] to the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the
+    /// client as hints of acceptable trust anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn add_hint_subject(mut self, subject: DistinguishedName) -> Self {
comment.body:
i think realistically either people will want to add to the existing hints, or have them empty -- i can't see why people would want to send _some_ hints, but not the ones for actual issuer names they trust.

how about `clear_root_hint_subjects(mut self)` (a good venue for recording that this means "clients will make a free choice of certificate to send" in a comment) and `add_root_hint_subjects(mut self, subjects: impl IntoIterator<Item = DistinguishedName>)`?

of course, those can be combined to set whatever contents someone likes.

issue.title: Debug bounds for customization traits

comment.body: I think adding `Debug` bounds for all traits outside of `internals` makes sense.

issue.title: Debug bounds for customization traits

comment.body:
Yeah, I think your logic about not requiring Debug for types at high risk of containing secrets makes sense. `KeyLog` probably doesn't contain secrets in general, but also I suspect most users will use one of the built-ins (`KeyLogFile` or `NoKeyLog`).

> I think to drop the custom Debug impl on ServerConfig and ClientConfig we'd also need to add a Debug bound on StoresServerSessions, ProducesTickets, and ResolvesClientCert

Yep. I didn't review all the traits but we can check them out here: https://docs.rs/rustls/latest/rustls/all.html#traits

BTW I don't think removing the custom Debug impl on ServerConfig needs to be a goal, but it's one place I noticed where we are omitting several fields because we can't print anything about them.

issue.title: Debug bounds for customization traits

comment.body: While we're considering this, I think to drop the custom `Debug` impl on `ServerConfig` and `ClientConfig` we'd also need to add a `Debug` bound on `StoresServerSessions`, `ProducesTickets`, and `ResolvesClientCert`

issue.title: Debug bounds for customization traits

comment.body:
Adding the `Debug` bound to the `ResolvesServerCert` seems like a good idea to me :+1:  For `KeyLog`, `ClientSessionStore`, and `Signer` I'm slightly hesitant.

As you mention, you need to take care implementing `Debug` for types that might contain sensitive data. I think most 
implementations of these traits are going to fall into that category. Adding a `Debug` bound will force downstream implementations to add code to satisfy the new requirement and I worry it will be tempting to `#[derive(Debug)]` as part of tidying up an upgrade's breaking changes without considering the potential for leaking something sensitive. We can call out the risk explicitly but I'm not sure I'm 100% convinced the reward is worth the risk. WDYT?

issue.title: Debug bounds for customization traits
cargo audit, webpki, and high severity vulnerability
issue.body:
Hello!

I ran `cargo audit` against our code base and the only vulnerability it flagged is a severity `high` in rustls-webpki 0.101.2 (see below). Our project does not have a direct dependency on it.  Instead, it comes through our usage of the current axum-server (v0.5.1) which used rustls (v0.21.5) which in tern is the one using rustls-webpki (v0.101.2).

I looked in the current open issues and didn't see anything logged to correct this so I thought I'd put something in the queue.

Thank you!

cargo audit report:

```
Crate:     rustls-webpki
Version:   0.101.2
Title:     rustls-webpki: CPU denial of service in certificate path building
Date:      2023-08-22
ID:        RUSTSEC-2023-0053
URL:       https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2023-0053
Severity:  7.5 (high)
Solution:  Upgrade to >=0.100.2, <0.101.0 OR >=0.101.4
Dependency tree:
rustls-webpki 0.101.2
└── rustls 0.21.5
    ├── tokio-rustls 0.24.1
    │   ├── rbdc 4.4.1
    │   │   ├── rbdc-sqlite 4.4.0
    │   │   │   └── securikey-server 1.7.0
    │   │   └── rbatis 4.4.2
    │   │       └── securikey-server 1.7.0
    │   └── axum-server 0.5.1
    │       └── securikey-server 1.7.0
    ├── rbdc 4.4.1
    └── axum-server 0.5.1

error: 1 vulnerability found!
```

cargo tree report indicating how it is pulled into my project:

```
 14 ├── axum-server v0.5.1
 13 │   ├── arc-swap v1.6.0
 12 │   ├── bytes v1.5.0
 11 │   ├── futures-util v0.3.28 (*)
 10 │   ├── http v0.2.9 (*)
  9 │   ├── http-body v0.4.5 (*)
  8 │   ├── hyper v0.14.27 (*)
  7 │   ├── pin-project-lite v0.2.13
  6 │   ├── rustls v0.21.5
  5 │   │   ├── log v0.4.20
  4 │   │   ├── ring v0.16.20
  3 │   │   │   └── untrusted v0.7.1
  2 │   │   │   [build-dependencies]
  1 │   │   │   └── cc v1.0.79
204 │   │   ├── rustls-webpki v0.101.2
  1 │   │   │   ├── ring v0.16.20 (*)
  2 │   │   │   └── untrusted v0.7.1
  3 │   │   └── sct v0.7.0
  4 │   │       ├── ring v0.16.20 (*)
  5 │   │       └── untrusted v0.7.1
  6 │   ├── rustls-pemfile v1.0.3
  7 │   │   └── base64 v0.21.4
  8 │   ├── tokio v1.33.0 (*)
  9 │   ├── tokio-rustls v0.24.1
 10 │   │   ├── rustls v0.21.5 (*)
 11 │   │   └── tokio v1.33.0 (*)
 12 │   └── tower-service v0.3.2
```

comment.body: Thank you @ctz @cpu and @djc .   `cargo update` resolved my issue as you all knew it would.  Excuse my ignorance being  about a 18 months new to Rust.  I came from a world where it was pretty taboo to change dependencies of packages upon which I indirectly use via my top-level dependencies.  Again the Rust system is nicer and safer.  And, I learned something new .  Thanks again

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +44,35 @@ impl ClientCertVerifierBuilder {
         }
     }
 
+    /// Replace the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the client as hints of acceptable trust
+    /// anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn with_hint_subjects(
+        mut self,
+        subjects: impl IntoIterator<Item = DistinguishedName>,
+    ) -> Self {
+        self.hint_subjects = subjects.into_iter().collect();
+        self
+    }
+
+    /// Add an additional [`DistinguishedName`] to the list of trust anchor subjects sent to the
+    /// client as hints of acceptable trust anchors during the TLS handshake.
+    ///
+    /// By default, the client cert verifier will [`RootCertStore::subjects`] with the root cert
+    /// store configured for client certificate authentication for the hint subjects.
+    ///
+    /// See [`ClientCertVerifier::client_auth_hint_root_subjects`] for more information on
+    /// circumstances where you may want to override the default hint subjects.
+    pub fn add_hint_subject(mut self, subject: DistinguishedName) -> Self {
comment.body:
> Maybe there's an argument to be made that this should be add_hint_subjects(mut self, subjects: impl IntoIterator<Item = DistinguishedName>)  for consistency and to make it easier to use with multiple names?

I ended up making this change. If you only have one `DistinguishedName` it's easy enough to make a slice to give, and in other cases the symmetry is helpful. 

> I wonder if we should use a different name for the replacing method? The with_() doesn't feel very explicit about appending vs replacing.

I left the name as-is (missed your edit), but I could change it to `replace_root_hint_subjects` if you think that would be more explicit.

pull_request.body:
This branch resolves https://github.com/rustls/rustls/issues/1549 by updating the default webpki client certificate verifier to allow configuring a server's client root certificate subject hints list separately from the subjects present in the root cert store used to verify client certificates. This is a useful capability in the presence of cross-signing when there are circumstances (described in #1549 and the updated rustdoc comments in this branch) where a server may want to hint to a client that it accepts a certificate with a given subject, without adding it to the server's trust store. 

See individual commit messages for more detail.

repo.name: rustls
repo.description: A modern TLS library in Rust

repo.name: rustls
repo.description: A modern TLS library in Rust

comment.body: Tightened this up to "Resolve a client certificate chain/private key to use as the client's identity.". I think from context it's clear enough that you make the resolution decision informed by the arguments, and the return type being `Option` gives enough of a hint that you can return `None`. We also spell out more detail about all of the above in the full comment past the headline.
